data.title: Film Adventurer Karel Zeman (2015)
data.meta_description: A look at the life, work and importance of Czech filmmaker Karel Zeman (1910-89), a genius of world cinema, a wizard of special effects, revealing his sources of inspiration and his revolutionary filming techniques.
data.text:
I've been fully immersing myself in the world of Czech animator/filmmaker Karel Zeman recently. From the spellbinding fantasy of Baron Munchausen to the adventurous A Thousand and One Nights, I've simply adored everything I've seen from Zeman. This documentary does an excellent job of painting a solid picture of a marketing creative, turned animator, turned filmmaker - with some genuinely engaging interviews with those that knew him or were inspired by his work.

Interestingly, this documentary bookends the bulk of the research and history with students from a Czech university animation/film course recreating sequences from Zeman's best known works with similar techniques. I've stated before that Zeman's approach to animation and filmmaking in general seems like absolute wizardy to me.…

☆"It wasn't what the bosses in Prague were looking for."☆

I so enjoyed the Criterion Collection box set of Karel Zeman films, restoring his three most notable features: Journey to the Beginning of Time, Invention for Destruction, and The Fabulous Baron Munchausen. It has a lot of extras too, including four short films and new brief interviews and analyses.

Naturally, there's a documentary feature on the Czech animator and director, so you know I'm down for that. Tomáš Hodan brings together all the clips and commentary in the informative work Filmový dobrodruh Karel Zeman ["Film Adventurer Karel Zeman"], a standard biodoc in most ways but definitely worth watching for new fans and devotees of Zeman's amazing style.

My favorite elements…
